awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Using dynamic energy landscapes to understand drivers of movement, foraging and life history patterns in albatrosses
awd_abstract_narration:
Changes in the environment impact where marine predators go to find food, and also how much energy these animals have to spend in reaching their foraging grounds. Assessing how foraging in marine animals is influenced by climate patterns is critical to understanding the future of marine ecosystems. We expect wind patterns to shift under predicted climate scenarios, and albatrosses, large seabirds that rely on wind to reach distant foraging areas, are strongly affected by wind patterns. Consequently, changes in the environment will likely have strong impacts on the movement and foraging behavior of albatrosses, as well as their ability to raise chicks successfully. This study will investigate how wind patterns influence the amount of energy that albatrosses have to spend when foraging, how this in turn impacts albatross reproduction, and how differences in wind patterns between El Niño and La Niña conditions influence the energetic cost of reaching foraging grounds. This work will take advantage of recent developments in tagging technology to generate estimates of energetic expenditure during albatross foraging trips. Education and outreach efforts will be integrated with research activities by: a) incorporating real-world scientific research into the New York State high school curriculum; b) developing novel and effective means of communicating my research with the public; and c) initiating a program to improve the retention and promotion of women in STEM fields.

Animal movement plays a central role in the ability of species to respond to changes in climate and other aspects of the environment, and is a major driver of biological processes from individuals to ecosystems. Fluid flow has important effects on the cost of transport and life history characteristics in flying and swimming animals, and many species have evolved to rely on global patterns of wind and ocean currents for migrations and foraging movements. Changes in the location and intensity of dominant wind patterns will have important consequences for the energetic costs of foraging, but the implications of these changes have not been explored in detail. This research develops a novel approach for understanding how environmental variability influences movement, foraging energetics and life history of North Pacific albatrosses. Proxies of energy expenditure measured in the field in real-time will be combined with innovative spatial approaches (energy landscapes) to develop a mechanistic model linking climate-driven variability in wind patterns to changes in albatross foraging energetics and life history.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Wind and waves are drivers of seabird movement and energetics that can influence seabird population trends, but a detailed understanding of how these environmental factors influence seabird energetics is lacking. Albatrosses are large, highly mobile seabirds that rely on energy gained from wind and waves to reach distant foraging areas across vast expanses of ocean, and as such are quintessential species through which to investigate how these factors influence seabirds. Albatross are thought to both use dynamic soaring, allowing them to extract energy from the wind, as well as wave-slope soaring, allowing them to use energy from waves for efficient flight. This research integrated data from targeted field studies and global wind and wave products to examine how wind affects the energy expenditure of albatross. Albatross were tagged with GPS loggers and 3D accelerometers, which allow measurements of fine-scale movements and estimates of energy expenditure to be derived. In addition, a subset of tagged birds was equipped with heart rate loggers, allowing estimates of energy expenditure to be ground-truthed against measurements of heart rate and estimates of VO2. We found that a frequently used metric of energy expenditure that is derived from accelerometer data, Overall Dynamic Body Acceleration (ODBA), was not a useful proxy of energy expenditure in albatross. ODBA assumes that rapid changes in acceleration are due to muscle contractions, but our research suggests that this assumption is violated since albatross use kinetic energy from the wind during soaring flight. However, we found that the number of wing flaps provides a useful metric of energy expenditure. Using flaps as a metric of energy expenditure, we assessed how wind and waves influenced flap rates in five species of albatross across two ocean basins. We found that albatross in the Southern Ocean were more strongly influenced by wind speed, while those in the North Pacific were better explained by variability in waves. Our results suggest that Southern Ocean species rely more on dynamic soaring using winds whereas North Pacific species rely more on wave-slope soaring using swells. Environmental differences likely drive this divergence behavior; while albatross in both regions experienced similar wind speeds, those in the North Pacific species experienced higher swell heights, likely allowing them to extract more wind energy from waves. We applied the relationships between wind, waves and energy expenditure to albatross GPS tracks collected over more than 20 years to estimate energy expenditure from wind and wave conditions along the tracks. Using these “dynamic energy landscapes”, we examined how wind impacts on individual energetics carried through to influence albatross populations using dynamic energy landscapes.  We found that wind and waves strongly influenced energy expenditure and travel speed, and were significant predictors of albatross breeding success.  These findings demonstrate that in addition to impacts on oceanographic habitats, climate-driven changes to wind and oceanography impact marine predators through impacts on the cost of travel and the energetic cost of reaching key habitats.

 Intellectual Merit: This research developed a novel approach for understanding how environmental variability influences foraging energetics and life history of threatened albatross species. This work combined recent methodological advances that allow proxies of energy expenditure to be measured in the field in real-time with innovative spatial approaches (energy landscapes) to develop a mechanistic model linking climate-driven variability in wind and waves to changes in albatross foraging energetics and life history.

Broader Impacts: Albatrosses are ideal species for illustrating links between climate and biological processes to broad audiences due to their charismatic nature and public appeal. As such, this research provided a unique opportunity to incorporate education and outreach efforts into research activities. Research and education were integrated in this project through a magazine article outlining research methods and findings aimed at the general public; lessons on seabird movement and biology for school children; and a mentoring program fostering the retention and promotion of women in STEM fields.
